skills.name: Solve problems that combine multiplication and division
Use direct proportion to solve non-unitary missing amounts in problems (e.g. recipes)
Identify compound units/unit rates from a situation

explanations.A: You have worked out the change from one year of sponsorship. Can you work out how many years of sponsorship you can afford with £80?
explanations.B: A year's cost is £2 × 12, so we need to work out how many years we will be able to buy with £80. The calculation is 80/(2 × 12)
explanations.C: You have divided 12 by 2. If we know the cost for 1 month then how would we find the cost for 12 months?
explanations.D: Consider the order of your division carefully. We need to start with the value we are sharing out (e.g. our £80)

explanations.A: You have worked out the change from one year of sponsorship. Can you work out how many years of sponsorship you can afford with £40?
explanations.B: You have divided 12 by 3. If we know the cost for 1 month then how would we find the cost for 12 months?
explanations.C: There are 12 months in a year so the cost per year is £3 × 12. Dividing £40 by this gives the number of years.
explanations.D: Consider the order of your division carefully. We need to start with the value we are sharing out (e.g. our £40).

explanations.A: We have 20Mb per 8 seconds. We can divide both numbers by 8 to get 2.5Mb per 1 second. This can be written as 2.5Mb/s.
explanations.B: I think you have tried to find 25% of 20. We do not need the percentage information to answer this question.
explanations.C: I think you have found 25% of 8. The percentage information is not needed here. If 20Mb will take 8 seconds to download, how many Mb can you download in 1 second?
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied 20 by 8. If 20Mb can be downloaded in 8 seconds, how many Mb can be downloaded in 1 second?

explanations.A: I think you have tried to use the 25%. We do not need the percentage information to answer this question.
explanations.B: I think you might have found 75% of 30 and then divided by 5. This would work if there were 30Mb in total, but there are 30Mb left. We don't actually need the percentage to work out the answer. If 30Mb will take 5 seconds to download, how many Mb can you download in 1 second?
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied 30 by 5. If 30Mb can be downloaded in 5 seconds, how many Mb can be downloaded in 1 second?
explanations.D: We have 30Mb left and this takes 5 seconds. We can divide both numbers by 5 to work out that 6Mb would take 1 second. This can be written as 6 Mb/s.

explanations.A: The scale factor is 60/24 = 2.5, so we divide 45 by 2.5 to get 18.
explanations.B: Did you divide the number of melons by 5? Or subtract 36? Dividing the stack by 5 will give us 9 melons but how many grapefruits will there be?
explanations.C: We can find a scale factor to help us here. What would I need to divide 60 by to get 24?
explanations.D: We don't need the same amount of melons to grapefruits. We just need them to be in the same proportion as the larger stack. We can find a scale factor to help us here. What would I need to divide 60 by to get 24?

explanations.B: We don't need the same amount of melons to grapefruits. We just need them to be in the same proportion as the larger stack. We can find a scale factor to help us here. What would I need to divide 60 by to get 10?
explanations.C: We can find a scale factor to help us here. What would we need to divide 60 by to get 10?
explanations.D: The number of grapefruits has been divided by 6 (from 60 to 10), so the number of melons will be divided by 6 as well. 36/6 = 6, so there will be 6 melons.
